body: Bias exists in everyone. We each need to be aware of our biases and how they impact the decisions we make. Identifying bias is the first step to addressing damaging biases–conscious or unconscious.
title: Course Info Text Title

_items.body: Writing-activity answers may be downloaded.
This course qualifies for CEU credit.

body: Understand our inherent biases and recognize their impact on behavior and results.

_complete.label: Scroll down to begin...

_incomplete.label: Scroll down to begin...

title: Objective text

body:
Individuals, groups, and institutions can all hold biases, and these biases can produce negative or positive consequences.


As you watch, consider what biases you have and how they impact your life and the lives of others.

_media._source: <video data-video-id="6012617349001"  data-account="1302165881001"  data-player="HkAiBMXk7"  data-embed="default"  data-application-id  class="video-js"  controls></video> <script src="//players.brightcove.net/1302165881001/HkAiBMXk7_default/index.min.js"></script>

title: Video Stream Title

body: To address bias, we must identify bias, cultivate connections with people different from ourselves, and act with courage to mitigate bias. These skills mutually reinforce each other when consistently applied.

_graphic.alt: Horizontal model with three interconnected circles displaying Identify Bias, Cultivate Connection, and Choose Courage

body: Uncovering unconscious bias starts with a change in thinking and may require reframing our frame of mind.

graphicText: Bias exists in everyone, including me. I actively think about how bias is at play in the choices I make.

body:
To become more aware of your biases:


  • Assess your biases.

title: Text Title

body: If you have a brain, you have biases. Biases are simply the result of how the brain operates or takes shortcuts.
title: Text Title

_incomplete.label: Select the options below to understand the differences.

body: Bias can be conscious or unconscious.
title: Text Title

_items.body:
• Is expressed directly.
  • Operates consciously.
  • Example: "Salespeople need to be extroverted."
_items.title: CONSCIOUS BIAS

_items.body:
• Is expressed indirectly.
  • Operates unconsciously.
  • Example: "This person just doesn't seem to fit in our team."
_items.title: UNCONSCIOUS BIAS

body: Listen to this example of how one organization's unconscious bias impacted customers.
title: UX Research

body:
• Bias is a preference for one thing, person, or group over another.
  • We all have biases—both conscious and unconscious.
  • To identify bias, we need to be self-aware.

_incomplete.label: Scroll down to finish this page...

_complete.label: Scroll down to finish this page...

title: Text Title

body: Bias affects each of us differently, and how we treat people can vary widely.

_items.body:
In the Damaging Zone, our ability to contribute is often impaired. When people intentionally or unintentionally behave in negative, hostile, or derogatory ways, they affect others’ emotional, mental, and physical well-being.


  • Abuse is an extreme behavior related to bias. Bias can even precipitate mental, physical, and verbal abuse.
  • Harassment happens when we actively point out differences to harm or cause a division. It is akin to bullying, because it attempts to control others or make them feel inferior.
  • Slighting often has the same effect as an insult, even though the slight is less direct. We may be unaware we are slighting others when unconscious bias is the cause.
_items.title: Damaging Zone

_items.body:
In the Limiting Zone, we aren't able to contribute fully. When others tolerate or ignore us, we can feel isolated and less likely to become engaged or contribute.


  • Ignoring other people or difficult issues is easy. However, ignoring people ultimately dehumanizes them and is only slightly removed from the "damaging" behaviors.
  • Tolerating someone is better than ignoring them, but it is still a limiting behavior. If you think about it, would you want to just be tolerated?
_items.title: Limiting Zone

_items.body:
In the High-Performance Zone, we feel respected, included, and valued. In this zone, we are engaged and we can make our fullest contributions.


  • Respect for others can open your eyes to new perspectives, ideas, and individuals, but it does not mean that everyone will always agree. Finding ways to work together while respecting differences can forge relationships and connections.
  • Including others involves finding opportunities to work together in new ways to everyone's benefit. As you include others, you begin to understand them better.
  • Valuing others is more than just respecting other people. It is actually recognizing their value and their perspectives, regardless of differences.
_items.title: High-Performance Zone

_complete.label: Select the zones below to learn more about the impacts of biased behaviors.

_incomplete.label: Select the zones below to learn more about the impacts of biased behaviors.

title: P2 Intro Hot Graphic Title

body: Ignored or tolerated behaviors are found in which of the following zones?

_incorrect.final:
That's incorrect!


The Limiting Zone includes ignored and tolerated behaviors. This is important to understand because some people feel ignoring an issue is okay, when it is actually limiting to others. Similarly, tolerating is a limiting behavior. After all, who would want to just be tolerated?
_incorrect.notFinal:
That's incorrect!


The Limiting Zone includes ignored and tolerated behaviors. This is important to understand because some people feel ignoring an issue is okay, when it is actually limiting to others. Similarly, tolerating is a limiting behavior. After all, who would want to just be tolerated?

That's incorrect!

_feedback.correct:

The Limiting Zone includes ignored and tolerated behaviors. This is important to understand because some people feel ignoring an issue is okay, when it is actually limiting to others. Similarly, tolerating is a limiting behavior. After all, who would want to just be tolerated?

title: Quick Check MCQ Title

_graphic.caption: In the United States and other Western nations, for every 1% increase in a woman's body mass, there is a ___% decrease in pay.

_items.title: 0.5%
_items.text: Women who don't fit the common mold of what a woman should look like get fewer opportunities. The study also implies that larger women have more limited marriage options, and that their partners are less likely to be successful.

_graphic.caption: Job seekers with non-Western names in Canada, the UK, the US, and Australia would have to submit ____% more resumes than a job seeker with a Western name in order to achieve the same result.

_items.title: 30%
_items.text: Western, Central, and Eastern Asian names were 40% less successful in small businesses and 20% less successful applying to larger corporations. There’s an automatic judgment about a person based solely on name. If the person isn't assumed to be part of the in-group, they may be dismissed.

_graphic.caption: In the UK, men are (more/less) likely to report being victims of domestic violence, hazing, or sexual assault.

_items.title: Less
_items.text: Men are three times as likely as women to not report what they are suffering. Of those men who do report, only 10% will report the abuse to the police.

_graphic.caption: While 50% of the US workforce identify as extroverts, they account for ____% of leaders and managers.

_items.title: 96%
_items.text: Even though only half of the population identify as extroverts, a staggering 96% of US leaders and managers self-identify as extroverts.

_graphic.caption: Among male CEOs of Fortune 500 companies, ____% are over 6 feet (180 centimeters) tall.

_items.title: 58%
_items.text: While only 14.5% of the US male population is 6 feet tall or taller, 58% of male CEOs of Fortune 500 companies are over six feet tall Height has little to do with the ability to lead a company, but clearly there is a perception that tall individuals are natural leaders.

_graphic.caption: LGBTQ+ youth are (more/less) than twice as likely to have attempted suicide compared to heterosexual youth.

_items.title: More than
_items.text: In most Western countries, LGBTQ+ youth are three to five times as likely to have attempted suicide as heterosexual youth.

_incomplete.label: Select each item to learn more.

_complete.label: Select each item to learn more.

body:

How you identify yourself and what you feel vulnerable about can often cause bias.
title: Text Title

_incomplete.label: Select below to read examples of identifiers above and beneath the surface.

_complete.label: Select below to read examples of identifiers above and beneath the surface.

body: Aspects of our identity are similar to an iceberg: some aspects are visible, while others lie underneath the surface. In some instances, people can conceal, highlight, or downplay their identity.
title: Text Title

_items.title: Obvious
_items.body:
Obvious identifiers:

  • Age
  • Race
  • Gender
  • Culture
  • Physical ability

_items.title: Hidden
_items.body:
Hidden identifiers:

  • Personality
  • Education
  • Religion
  • Skills
  • Experience
  • Family
  • Wealth

_incomplete.label: Select below to read examples of identifiers above and beneath the surface...

_complete.label: Select below to read examples of identifiers above and beneath the surface...

body:
Concealing or downplaying your identifiers can make you seem inauthentic, and yet doing so can also protect you from negative outside biases.


Highlighting an aspect of your identity can empower you, and some identities are associated with all sorts of benefits.
title: Text Title

body: Which of the following is an obvious identifier?

_incorrect.final:
That's incorrect!


Wearing a sports-team jersey is an example of an obvious identifier because it is visible and on the surface. Personality, number of siblings, and educational background are not things people can typically see by looking at you.
_incorrect.notFinal:

title: Quick Check MCQ Title

body:
• When we are biased, we can make errors or miss valuable information or perspectives of others.
  • Our biases can limit our own performance or make us behave in ways that limit others.
  • Our personal identity can create biases that lead to both positive and negative outcomes for ourselves and others.
  • We progress when we notice, own, learn from, and address our biases.
title: Summary text

body: Because identity and experiences shape biases, and because many aspects of both identity and experience are subconscious, our brains automatically create biases to help us cope.

body: Because of _____, we can pause and rewire our thinking to stop taking biased-based shortcuts.

_feedback.correct:
That's correct!


Neuroplasticity is the ability of the brain to change, regardless of someone’s age. When we pause and become aware of our thought processes, we can rewire our thinking to stop taking bias-based shortcuts.

body: Which of the following is NOT one of the three bias traps?

_feedback.correct:
That's correct!


Trial and Error is not a bias trap. Need for Speed, Information Overload, and Feelings Over Facts are the three bias traps.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
That's incorrect!


Trial and Error is not a bias trap. Need for Speed, Information Overload, and Feelings Over Facts are the three bias traps.
_partlyCorrect.final:

title: Quick Check MCQ Title

_items.body:
Confirmation Bias

We tend to seek information that supports our existing beliefs. 


Anchoring Bias

We tend to rely on the first piece of information we see.
_items.title: "Information Overload" Biases

_items.body:
In-Group Bias

We tend to favor people we like and who are like us, while excluding and judging those who are different.


Negativity Bias

We are more powerfully influenced by negative experiences than positive or neutral experiences.
_items.title: "Feelings Over Facts" Biases

_items.body:
Attribution Bias

We judge others on their actions, but we judge ourselves based on our intent. 


Sunk-Cost Bias

We tend to continue things because we’ve invested time, money, or resources into them.
_items.title: "Need for Speed" Biases

body: Over 180 biases have been documented that can affect our decision making. Use the arrows to click through and learn about some of the more common biases.
title: Narrative Title

body: Which two biases are associated with the "Feelings Over Facts" bias trap?

_feedback.correct:
That's correct!


Negativity Bias and In-Group Bias are related to the "Feelings Over Facts" bias trap.


In-Group Bias is the tendency to be more helpful and positive toward members of our own group over members of an out-group. We feel good about people who are like us.


Negativity Bias is the tendency for us to focus or dwell on negative experiences. Something very positive will generally have less of an impact on a person’s behavior than something equally emotional but negative.

_partlyCorrect.final:
That's incorrect!

Negativity Bias is the tendency for us to focus or dwell on negative experiences. Something very positive will generally have less of an impact on a person’s behavior than something equally emotional but negative.

_incorrect.final:

title: Quick Check MCQ Title

body:
Biases impact the business world.


Employees who feel they are the target of bias are three times more likely to disengage, withhold ideas, and leave their job within the first year of employment.
title: Text Title

graphicText:
Companies in the top 25% on gender and racial diversity are more likely to over-perform in relation to their industry peers.


"Delivering Through Diversity," McKinsey & Company
title: Graphic Title

graphicText:
Companies in the lowest 25% on gender and racial diversity are 25% more likely to under-perform in relation to their industry peers.

"Delivering Through Diversity," McKinsey & Company
title: Graphic Title

body: Listen to how one organization identified and addressed a significant bias. As you listen, think about how you can address your own biases.

title: Blind Auditions

body:
• No idea is more fundamental than how we see ourselves and each other.
  • The way our brains work to process information creates biases.
  • When we understand what bias is, we can unleash our own and others’ potential.
  • Three bias traps cause our brains to create shortcuts that can lead us into biased thinking and behavior.
